search_result.title: Thanks for sharing the table: It's time for life's dessert
search_result.text:
Sylvia Rector

Detroit Free Press Restaurant Critic

Last month, I gave up the best job in the world — one that hundreds of you would have killed for, figuratively speaking. Or so you told me many times when I met you socially or on assignment over my 17 years as the Detroit Free Press restaurant critic.

It was the best occupation in the world in many ways, but not solely for the reasons you think.

True, my job was to dine in restaurants all over metro Detroit and sometimes far beyond, with the Free Press picking up the tab for me and my dining companions. And then I had the privilege of expressing my opinions about those places on the pages and website of Michigan’s largest daily newspaper.

But for me, an equally satisfying part of the job was interviewing, and eventually coming to know, many of Michigan’s best chefs and restaurateurs: men and women who made time to tell me — and thus, you — their stories; to share their vision of food and hospitality; to explain the inner workings of their industry; and sometimes to allow me behind the scenes, into the best professional kitchens, to watch and learn what it takes to create truly great food.

The 7 most-asked questions I heard as restaurant critic

My job was an education I treasure.

This is the last article I will byline as the Free Press restaurant critic.

So just as chefs invited me behind the scenes to learn more about their world, I thought I’d pull back the curtain on mine, giving you a glimpse into the sublime, ever-changing, fun, often stressful, heartburn-inducing, all-consuming job it really was.

And then I’ll tell you why I gave it up.

The job (most) everyone wants

The job I took when I was named restaurant critic in 1999 is a galaxy away from the one I had when I left — an evolution driven by mega changes in technology, media and the public’s knowledge of and interest in food.

I loved the job as it was when I started. But even more, I loved the competitive, higher-profile job it became, despite the trade-offs it required.

When I began writing some restaurant reviews in 1998 — my title was still food writer then — critics were expected to wait three months to set foot in a new restaurant so it could smooth out. The paper ran one major review a week, and we generally followed national Association of Food Journalists’ guidelines at the time, visiting anonymously multiple times with guests before writing a review and awarding stars.

Often, the review was the first word we had printed about the place (previews of upcoming restaurants were rare), and the review ran with a couple of photos shot by Free Press photographers.

In retrospect, it seems quaint.

By the time I left the Free Press, I was writing many restaurant stories each week, and the job was as much about competitive news coverage — vying for first word or new exclusive content about a place before it opened — as it was about dining somewhere and writing a thoughtful critique.

The sheer number of restaurants and food-related businesses had increased exponentially, the interest in food and dining was through the roof, and a whole crowd of websites and blogs had sprung up to focus on it. Waiting weeks or months to review a high-profile restaurant was out of the question; by then, it felt like old news.

So rather than award stars based on only one visit, I began writing un-starred First Looks, critiquing the six or seven dishes I had tried and describing the menu, decor and service. It wasn’t as thorough as the old way, but it was transparent and served readers well.

Digital photography changed the job, too.

The increased interest in food demanded more, I thought, than a couple of photos with reviews, but the paper couldn’t send a photographer everywhere I went. So, still dining anonymously, I began carrying a small digital camera and shooting my plates at the table.

Servers and other diners sometimes shot me disapproving looks, but most probably figured I was just another blogger or Yelper and didn’t question me. Other servers, though, were pleased I found the plates so pretty that I wanted pictures of them. Occasionally, one would notice my camera and ask whether my husband and I would like to have our picture taken at the table. The only polite answer was yes, so I’d hand over the camera and we would pose, smiling.

Using social media added work, too, but Twitter and Facebook could deliver news quickly and reach wider audiences, so they became another part of the job. Last year, I added some podcasts to the list and made my video reporting debut with a marathon food-truck review from the Mo Pop music festival.

Perhaps the most difficult change for me was the dropping of my anonymity in early 2015. I preferred staying in the background and letting my work speak for me, but my smart, ever-supportive editors had other ideas.

They wanted me visible, doing TV interviews, making public appearances on the paper’s behalf and meeting readers at events like last year’s Top 10 Takeover dinners at the year’s Best New Restaurants.

Those turned out to be some of the most fun events of my career.

Scores of interesting, friendly, food-loving readers came from across metro Detroit and beyond to try restaurants I had chosen and to hear what the chefs or owners and I had to say about them. It was humbling to hear so many people say they had read me “forever” and trusted what I wrote.

The critic of 17 years ago would have had a heart attack at the thought of so many broken “rules.”

But the rules and the world had changed.

The evolution of dining

As the job evolved, so, too, did food, dining styles and our tastes.

Over those 17 years, I saw and chronicled the arrival of the local-foods and farm-to-table movement, nose-to-tail cooking, food trucks, coffee culture, craft breweries and distilleries, artisan bakeries, and the most fundamental change of all — the casualization of dining. It was a period that saw the closing of many classic fine-dining restaurants, from the acclaimed Golden Mushroom in Southfield to the legendary Lark, just last month, in West Bloomfield.

Cocktails had a revival. Charcuterie came back from near extinction. Chefs with fine-dining backgrounds led the barbecue trend. Pop-ups arrived, first in empty warehouses and now in restaurants devoted exclusively to them. We transitioned from huge entrées to shared plates. Sushi stopped being “scary”; even Kroger sells it. And once little-known ethnic cuisines, flavors and dishes — especially Asian ones — have become mainstream.

Chefs now credit farmers, dairies and foragers on their chalkboards and menus. Diners expect vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free dishes everywhere they go. Issues including animal cruelty, ocean depletion and the genetic modification of ingredients affect our decisions about what to order.

My right-hand man

Restaurant critics have to eat — a lot. Or at least, they have to eat many different things at many different places and at all kinds of times. The timid and picky need not apply. They need an iron stomach, unlimited curiosity and a willingness to walk into places where they clearly don’t belong to buy or order foods they may never have tried before.

Critics also need flexible schedules and a willing dining partner who will go anywhere with almost no notice, in the worst possible weather, order whatever they’re told to, and let the critic freely eat off their plate. They’ll act as a decoy, asking questions on the critic’s behalf (so the critic doesn’t attract attention) to see how the server responds and even make sure the critic’s camera battery is charged before leaving home.

Meet my husband, Charles Hill, without whom I couldn’t have done my job nearly as well. I was paid to spend my nights, weekends and social life racing to restaurants all over metro Detroit — but he wasn’t. Still, he was always there, even when it wasn’t fun.

There were times I had to go out four or five nights in a single week — even when I longed to stay home in my PJs and nurse a crummy cold.

There were many Saturdays when we had to hit five or six different places so I could fill the last two slots in a Freep Five roundup of “Five Great Places for... ” whatever. Whether it was mac-and-cheese, chicken potpie or Italian sub sandwiches, by the time I was done, I didn’t want to see another one for months.

But Freep Fives paled in comparison with the ambitious (or foolhardy) roundups I undertook in 2008 and 2009 of metro Detroit’s 21 Best Sandwiches, 25 Top Burgers and 25 Best Pizzas, among others. I would ask readers to send me nominations, read the scores of replies, and then spend weeks trying the ones that sounded best, along with those I already knew.

The most brutal was burgers: burger after burger — some 60 of them — served in diners, dive bars and nice restaurants from Ann Arbor to the Grosse Pointes. I’d drive to the place, go in and order, wait for the food, take numerous photos, eat several bites, ask for a box and my bill, and drive to another place, for almost a month.

And for the pizza roundup, so many empty boxes stacked up in the garage, I was embarrassed on trash pickup days, wondering what the neighbors might think.

For the love of food

But I also had the privilege of dining regularly at the kinds of places most people visit only once or twice, if ever. They left me with memories, still vivid many years later, of eye-opening ingredients, exquisite dishes and beautiful scenes. But so did so many wonderful everyday places that I return to, time and again.

When I flip back through my mental snapshots, I remember first tasting the imported Italian buffalo mozzarella at Bacco in Southfield; the lobster whipped cream that topped the scallops at Cuisine in Detroit; the sensation of Mangalitsa pork lardo (cured fat) melting on my tongue at Forest Grill in Birmingham, and the surprise of sea salt — then unheard-of — in the chocolate and caramel filling of The Egg dessert at the old Tribute in Farmington Hills.

I remember the crispy coating on the hand-dipped cod at iconic Scotty Simpson’s Fish and Chips in Detroit; the world’s-best corned beef hash at the Beverly Hills Grill, and the addictive roasted vegetable sandwich at the Russell Street Deli in Eastern Market.

I remember the taste of sweet-corn foam on a tiny dish at the now-closed Torino in Ferndale; seeing the sun dip under the horizon from the dining room of Coach Insignia atop the Renaissance Center, and watching the chef-owner of Mabel Gray in Hazel Park rocking out to the music while cooking in his open kitchen.

I remember drinking wine late into the night with my husband on the evergreen-bordered patio at Assaggi in Ferndale; sitting at the chef’s counter at Selden Standard in Detroit, watching pork belly roast over flames a few feet away, and I remember, starting back in 1999, the shocked reactions of the 16 people I told that I was naming their restaurant Free Press Restaurant of the Year.

Snapshots. Hundreds of snapshots. So many more than I can recount here.

So many flavors, so many faces

My job allowed me to meet and interview some of the food world’s most interesting people, including the legendary Julia Child, with whom I spent an afternoon in Ann Arbor. I asked her what three essential dishes one should learn to cook to feed themselves well. “That’s a very good question!” she trilled, and after a moment’s thought, listed a roast chicken, a nice salad and a proper omelet. It’s still a perfect list. I’ll never part with the interview tape.

I sat in the kitchen at Tribute and drank wine with mesmerizing chef Eric Ripert of New York’s Le Bernardin, who told me one of his most useful skills as a chef was being able to speak Spanish to the cooks in his very French kitchen.

I had breakfast with Anthony Bourdain, who admitted he had mellowed since becoming a father; I think he got over it. Iron Chef Michael Symon, the owner of Roast and a wonderfully genuine guy, showed me his pig tattoos. And Wolfgang Puck talked passionately at age 63 about the importance of always changing with the times.

I came to know many excellent servers and managers and was befriended by talented sommeliers and bartenders. I learned the importance of dishwashers. And I truly loved writing about amazing Michigan farmers and growers and food producers like the three men I dubbed Detroit’s Kings of Corned Beef.

But the people I’ll remember best were the chefs and owners I came to know over many years of reviewing their restaurants, interviewing them for a wide variety of stories, and simply observing them at work.

As wildly different as their personalities are, the best of them share some important characteristics.

So rather than name anyone individually (because I can’t name them all), I’ll tell you what they seem to have in common, starting with the fierce pride they take in their work. They eschew short cuts; believe that great food starts with the best ingredients; and never stray too long or too far from their kitchens.

Even under the gruffest exteriors, most are driven by a need to feed, please and take care of others. They are leaders, teachers and team-builders. They set high standards, work incredibly hard and expect others to do the same. And whether they are 25 or 55, their passion for food is worn on their sleeves.

The best party ever

Metro Detroit’s restaurant scene is the best it has ever been, and it will only get better.

If the Free Press hadn’t offered senior employees a nice financial package to retire, I’d still be at my desk right now — or probably dining somewhere, taking pictures of Plate No. 16,572, or whatever.

But I’ve had a lot to eat. Life is short. And I believe in leaving the party when it’s still going strong.

Last year — when I turned 65 and marked 23 years at the Freep — was the best party ever, so this feels like the right time to slip out the kitchen door and become a civilian diner.

Thanks, everyone, for reading. It has been a pleasure and a privilege. I’ll be on Facebook and Twitter @SylviaRector, so let me know if a great new place opens up.

search_result.title: Andrew Luck: Colts quarterback — and foodie
search_result.text:
Liz Biro

liz.biro@indystar.com

Colts quarterback Andrew Luck plays hard. So when he sits down to eat, it's steak and potatoes, right? Or a pork tenderloin sandwich.

Not so much.

I talked to Luck this week about his role in Quaker Make the Play, a contest in which you can win a day of play with Luck by submitting a video showing a game your family invented.

But I couldn't resist asking Luck about his growing foodie reputation, especially on the heels of a recent conversation on my Facebook page where some people insisted Indianapolis has hardly any decent ethnic food.

Luck not only finds ethnic food, he prefers it.

"I think that India Garden has a great chicken tikka masala," Luck said, of the 207 N. Delaware St. restaurant.

"And then for good Thai food, Siam Square's pad Thai. And they have a good praram long song." Siam Square is at 936 Virginia Ave., in Fountain Square.

Chicken tikka masala puts tandoori oven-roasted chicken in a spicy, creamy sauce. Praram long song is a dish of meat (chicken at Siam Square) and vegetables in peanut curry sauce.

But you don't have to define exotic-sounding dishes to Luck. His taste for foreign food, he said, comes from growing up overseas and living in London. Luck's father, former Houston Oilers quarterback Oliver Luck, worked for NFL Europe.

When I asked Luck if he had checked out some ethnic neighborhood haunts, he immediately asked for suggestions on where to go.

"My girlfriend sort of will go out and explore. She got really into southern Indian cuisine. She brought home some dosa (Indian fermented rice crepe). And some Greek food from Greek Islands (906 S. Meridian St.)."

Luck liked it all. He's adventurous. Fellow players note his taste for octopus. He has revealed a refrigerator stocked with stinky cheese and local duck prosciutto.

Luck sounded excited when I suggested a Lafayette Square-area African restaurant (NairaLand at Beautiful Shades, 4718 Century Plaza Road) and Indian grocer (Om India Plaza, 4225 Lafayette Road).

Do gourmet ingredients in Luck's fridge mean he cooks?

"I am trying much harder this year to cook more," he said. "Breakfast is easy to cook; I've gotten good at that" (he likes yogurt on his oatmeal).

"It's a nice respite to come home and cook dinner."

Luck's signature dish has, as you might expect, international flair. "My only specialty dish is one that I stole from my mom," he admitted.

She calls it "Chicken Marbella," Luck said. From his description of its garlic, prunes, olives and Mediterranean herbs, it sounds like a recipe of the same name from the famous 1980s gourmet foodie tome "The Silver Palate Cookbook" (Workman). Chicken Marbella was one of the book's most popular recipes.

Luck, 24, doesn't have a Twitter account. Social media, a place where many foodies share dining experiences, is not his thing. He discovers where and what to eat the old-fashioned way.

"Word of mouth, friends talking about it. The paper, the magazines," Luck said. "But generally word of mouth."

Call Liz Biro at (317) 444-6264. Follow her on Twitter: @lizbiro.

Chicken Marbella

Yield: 16 pieces, 10 or more portions

1/2 cup olive oil

1/2 cup red wine vinegar

1 cup pitted prunes

1/2 cup pitted Spanish green olives

1/2 cup capers with a bit of juice

6 bay leaves

1 head of garlic, peeled and finely pureed

1/4 cup dried oregano

Coarse salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste

4 chickens (2 1/2 pounds each), quartered

1 cup brown sugar

1 cup dry white wine

1/4 cup fresh Italian (flat-leaf) parsley or fresh cilantro, finely chopped

1. Combine the olive oil, vinegar, prunes, olives, capers and juice, bay leaves, garlic, oregano, and salt and pepper in a large bowl. Add the chicken and stir to coat. Cover the bowl and refrigerate overnight.

2. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.

3. Arrange the chicken in a single layer in one or two large, shallow baking pans and spoon the marinade over it evenly. Sprinkle the chicken pieces with brown sugar and pour the white wine around them.

4. Bake, basting frequently with the pan juices, until the thigh pieces yield clear yellow (rather than pink) juice when pricked with a fork, 50 minutes to 1 hour.

5. With a slotted spoon, transfer the chicken, prunes, olives, and capers to a serving platter. Moisten with a few spoonfuls of the pan juices and sprinkle generously with the parsley or cilantro. Pass the remaining pan juices in a sauce boat.

Note: To serve Chicken Marbella cold, cool to room temperature in the cooking juices before transferring the pieces to a serving platter. If the chicken has been covered and refrigerated, reheat it in the juices, then allow it to come to room temperature before serving. Spoon some of the reserved juice over the chicken.

Silver Palate Products used in this recipe: Nonpareil Capers in White Balsamic Vinegar

Source: "The Silver Palate Cookbook" via www.silverpalate.com.

search_result.title: Take 10: These eateries whet the appetite
search_result.text:
Mary Bergin

Time to review life as you know it, and I'll do the same as 2015 ends. These restaurants, close to home and many miles away, caught my attention this year.

•Café Hollander, Madison: The Milwaukee-based restaurateur opened this third location in autumn, but "café" is an understatement because the array of options is large. Belgian beers are the specialty, Bloody Marys are prepared seven ways and the "bier mosa" mixes o.j. with a wheat brew. To eat: beignets with lemon and chocolate dipping sauces, waffles topped with bourbon pecan butter, four types of toppings for toast (honey, roasted apples and brie herbal cheese is one). That's just breakfast, and just for starters. Also in Wauwatosa and Milwaukee. cafehollander.com, 608-237-3168

•Tom+Chee, Appleton and Elm Grove: Tomato soup with a grilled cheese spells pure comfort, but that combo needs further clarification when ordered at this quick-service franchise. Building a sandwich goes far beyond white versus wheat and cheddar versus swiss: Try melting your favorite fromage between slices of a glazed doughnut. Or add a layer of potato chips for extra crunch. Classic, creamy and chunky versions of tomato soup are sold by the little dipper, cup or bowl. These are menu headliners for the Cincinnati business that gained bigtime exposure through "Shark Tank" and other nationwide TV spots. Now there are 34-and-counting locations. tomandchee.com, 920-815-3059, 414-249-5206

•Bonaparte Retreat Restaurant, Bonaparte, Iowa: The community? Population 433, on the Des Moines River in southeast Iowa. The restaurant? In a restored, century-old grist mill. A flood and fire nearly destroyed the town in 1903; Iowans know the hamlet today as a rural dining delight because of hand-cut steaks and chops for dinner, lunchtime blue plate specials and breaded pork tenderloins. Save room for pie; the thick strawberry puree sells out fast in summer. The setting – exposed beans, old brick walls, antique cash register, eclectic collectibles – feels like a homey museum. bonaparteretreat.com, 319-592-3339

•Bourbon and Baker, Manhattan, Kan.: Southern and Midwest influences converge in the front end of this college town business, which stocks 70 kinds of bourbon, serves whiskey punch/whiskey-ritas and presents a compact menu of sliders (kobe or oyster), tacos (duck), fries (asparagus), waffles (with chicken) and other unpredictable fare. Enter through the back door, and you'll find a bakery primping cookies, fancy cakes, buns and biscuits for both this building and neighboring Harry's, genteel dining in a historic hotel structure downtown. bbmanhattan.com, 785-320-4959

•Lunchbox Laboratory, Seattle: How lucky that the nearest sit-down restaurant to our Seattle hotel (northeast of downtown) was this unusual and affordable eatery. Burgers rule, but they are made with your choice of beef, lamb, a veggie black bean combo, churken (ground chicken and turkey) or "dork" (pork and duck). Sides and sauces include black truffle mayo, bread and butter pickle tartar. Match the meal with a booze-spiked milk shake; other beverages arrive in beakers, test tubes. The motif is both nostalgic and edgy, thanks to a collection of oldtime lunchboxes that are treated like modern art. Other outlets are in Bellvue and Gig Harbor, Wash. lunchboxlaboratory.com, 206-621-1090

•New York Wine and Culinary Center, Canandaigua, N.Y.: Every state should have a beautiful stage like this for local food and beverage products. The many fine wines of the Finger Lakes region (plus New York craft beer, spirits) are available by the sampling, serving or bottle. Also in the nonprofit enterprise is a gift shop, Upstairs Bistro restaurant and two roomy classrooms for hands-on workshops and cooking demos (these frequent sessions last one to three hours). The bistro menu lists farms that provide key ingredients for brunch, lunch and dinner; seating overlooks Canandaigua Lake. nywcc.com, 585-394-7070

•Sea Salt, St. Petersburg Fla.: Ask for salt at most restaurants, and it's passed as an afterthought. Not so here, where a Kalamanak from India, pink Himalayan and black Hiwa Kai from Hawai tops each table. For sale are many of the 130 salts and infusions that are carefully matched to each course of fine dining. Chef Fabrizio Aielli, a Venice native, is responsible for the emphasis and excess. Little seems modest at the St. Petersburg venue, open since autumn 2015 in the Sundial dining/shopping complex, where the raw bar is 80 feet long and a tower of wines is 20 feet tall. Also in Naples. seasaltstpete.com, 727-873-7964; seasaltnaples.com, 239-263-1955

•Fish on Fire, Orlando: I don't expect much when booking a quick overnight at a cheap motel with an airport shuttle because of a late-arriving flight. Steps away, in this case, was the friendly Fish on Fire, whose name acknowledges a 2010 kitchen fire. This locals' hangout was opened by a couple of fishing buddies who are fussy about the quality of their daily catches. Cooks also will cook your catch and serve it family style. The mood is laid back, décor funky and band bookings frequent on weekends. fishonfireorlando.com, 407-812-6881

•Glutton, Las Vegas: Count brown butter gnocchi and caramel corn profiteroles in chef and co-owner Joseph Kudrak's ambitious repertoire, served downtown in an intimate restaurant whose location and character are far from the clamor and glitz of casinos. Consider barrel-aged cocktails at the bar, yeast-risen pancakes for brunch, ahi tuna tacos for lunch, calamari fries or bacon and fig flatbread to nibble with a friend. gluttonlv.com, 702-366-0623

•Cebicheria La Mar, Lima, Peru: Avenida La Mar is a street in the Miraflores district near downtown, known for restaurants that specialize in ceviche (raw seafood that "cooks" via citrus marinades). An anchor is celebrity chef Gaston Acurio's crowded and casual eatery that ranks among the best for ceviche in Latin America. It can be adventurous dining: melt-in-your-mouth sea urchins, grilled octopus, fresh-as-it-comes fish. Also in Miami, San Francisco, Bogota and Sao Paulo. lamarcebicheria.com/lima, 511-421-3365

search_result.title: Wildwood-area dining: 10 new restaurants to try in 2023
search_result.text:
On the Jersey Shore, the Wildwoods are as known for their painstaking preservation of the Doo Wop days of yore as for the famously wide white sand beaches — a motel and diner ode to the days of rock ’n’ roll. Generations of families from Delaware and Philadelphia and all over Jersey return each summer without fail, for mood as much as seafood.

But each year, the island also renews itself. And the off-season has been particularly busy this year, with a host of new places to eat and drink.

The biggest developments in the area will be big indeed: a 180-seat hotel steak and seafood restaurant with a beat-thumping pool bar and nightclub next door, and a hulking entertainment complex with a pair of restaurants in Rio Grande. A Philly cheesesteak icon plans a new outpost in Wildwood, and so does a Brooklyn sandwich shop braiding its own fresh mootz.

Families coming back to the Wildwood area will also find plenty of new homespun offerings, whether scratch-made crab gnocchi from an old family recipe, Mediterranean tapas in a revived century-old movie theater or the novel treat of cereal-swirled ice cream.

Here’s the rundown on 10 new spots to eat and drink in and around the Wildwoods.

Holiday deals: Shop this season’s top products and sales curated by our editors.

Italian and seafood on the Wildwood Boardwalk at Stephen’s Restaurant

401 E. Wildwood Ave., Wildwood, 609-849-9037, stephens-restaurant.com. Breakfast and dinner.

Stephen’s Restaurant opened just this April on the Wildwood boardwalk. But history here runs deep.

The recipe for chef Stephen Quici’s laboriously handmade gnocchi comes from his Southern Italian grandmother — slathered in blush sauce and jumbo lump crab — and so does the kitchen table he rolls out the gnocchi on.

The painting of the Last Supper on the wall? That was his grandfather’s. Paint by numbers.

Quici will blend two old traditions at Stephen's: Shore seafood and family Italian, from sauteed chicken or veal in wine sauce to Shore-classic crab gravy to an Italian fishermen’s stew of mussels, clams, shrimp, lobster and scallops.

The Philly native has been coming to Wildwood since he was a child. And so decades ago, Quici also remembers eating a $10.99 lobster-filet mignon surf and turf at the old boardwalk lobster shack that used to be where Stephen’s now stands.

In honor, he offers the same dish on his own menu. “Unfortunately, I couldn’t do $10.99,” he said, laughing.

But the restaurant's history also goes back to Philly, where Quici opened another Stephen’s Restaurant two decades back. Before he was even officially open in Wildwood, some of his old customers drove hours to eat his food again.

“They recognized me, and I recognized them,” Quici said. “It was a very humbling experience.”

Tapas in a cheer-filled movie theater: Old Movies by the Sea

4005 Pacific Ave., Wildwood. oldmoviesbythesea.com.

More than a century ago, the little building at 4005 Pacific Ave. opened as a what was then called a nickelodeon: a 5-cent theater showing a new and wondrous thing called “motion pictures.”

That theater likely closed in the 1920s, and in the meantime, the building’s been a baby clothes store, a shop selling musical instruments and a performing arts theater.

But last fall, partners Glenn Kingsbury and Karen Drew restored the old place back to its original glory as a plush-walled 40-seat moviehouse showing films from the golden age. The pair has also been hosting live comedy, birthday parties and even cheerleading competitions: Kingsbury runs cheer contests under the name Spirit Brands, and the theater is now a new home to competitive enthusiasm.

But as tourist season begins, Old Movies by the Sea will be a place to get dinner with a show. The theater’s manager, Jeff Levine, once cooked at restuarants in New York. And so the movie theater's food menu is an ambitious mix of tapas and catering fare: honeyed shrimp with walnuts, bacon-wrapped dates, Thai-spiced skewers and thick-meated “pinwheels” that look a bit like stromboli.

Order when you buy your movie or comedy tickets, and the food will be yours when you arrive.

Cereal-ice cream swirls: Utterly Ice Cream, Cereal and Coffee Bar

3411 Pacific Ave., Wildwood, 609-522-0590. Open mornings to 2 p.m. and in the evening.

The Wildwoods, like the foodies of TikTok, are undergoing a bit of a cereal frenzy.

Last year, North Wildwood saw the opening of a coffee bar called McCoy’s with cereal and cereal-topped doughnuts. This year, another turn of the screw: Utterly, near the Wildwood boardwalk, offers cereal-infused ice cream.

More:6 new restaurants in Wildwood to check out this summer

After running an ice cream shop at the nearby Yankee Clipper motel, owner Danielle Aydelotte has moved on to crunchier pastures with Utterly. Her new ice cream, cereal and coffee bar allows customers to choose a cereal among any of a dozen options ranging from Cap’n Crunch to Froot Loops to seasonal flavors like a recent Peeps cereal, then choose an ice cream flavor they want to mix it with.

Aydelotte can then blend the cereal and ice cream together using a machine called the Swirl Freeze. She’d first seen the notion on the internet, she said — and then she had to try it.

“You get the silky smoothness of the ice cream,” Aydelotte said, “and you have a tiny bit of crunch from the cereal.”

From there, each soft-serve cone can then be drizzled with white chocolate or fudge or other flavors.

Utterly’s coffee offerings are also betting on breakfast, with cereal-infused milk customers can mix into their coffee.

“This was our first week that we put out the Cinnamon Toast Crunch-infused milk,” she said. “And we pretty much sold out of that within the first day or two."

Flapjacks and a mission: Brandon’s Pancakes and Ice Cream Parlor

6200 New Jersey Ave., Wildwood Crest, 609-305-4807.In his high school yearbook at Cape May Regional, Karl Famiano declared he would one day own a pancake house. And in Wildwood Crest’s former Doo-Wop Drive-Thru, Famiano finally made good on that pledge.

Brandon’s Pancakes and Ice Cream Parlor opened this April with pancakes and biscuits and gravy in the morning, hoagies and ribeye cheesesteaks at lunch.

But the pancake house picked up a new mission along the way. Brandon’s is a place designed to be welcoming and inclusive to people with autism — and indeed to all people.

Aimee Famiano, Karl’s wife and partner in the restaurant, is a longtime special needs educator. Upon moving to the Shore from Pennsylvania, she noted that there were relatively few resources for people like her 25-year-old son, Brandon, nonverbal and living with autism.

And so the pancake house that bears his name is also a place where Brandon can work and call his own.

“He contributes, and he’s kind of like the little mayor,” Aimee Famiano said. “He walks around and shakes people’s hands.”.

Brandon’s also provides employment for other people in Cape May County with special needs, and the Famianos have teamed with local schools to offer both work training and a destination for field trips.

And if the food sometimes comes out a little slower than at some short-order kitchens, so be it. Famiano asks folks to be a little patient.

“We're not only here to make money,” she said. “We're here to be warm and kind and employ people who need it, and show them kindness and compassion.”

Vietnamese soups and banh mi at Cape May Pho and Boba

709 Route 9 South, Cape May Court House, 609-536-2545. Lunch and dinner.

Though the towns surrounding Atlantic City have long been home to a bustling Vietnamese dining scene, a steaming bowl of pho has not been an easy find on the Cape.

As of last fall, owners Thao “Tracey” Le, and husband Tai Pham, changed all that with a pho and boba shop in Cape May Courthouse serving bubble teas and scratch-made pho prepared for as long as 48 hours — not to mention a broad menu of Vietnamese classics. Le’s extended family helps out with preparation, she told the Cape May County Herald in January.

In addition to pho, the menu includes banh mi sandwiches, vermicelli noodle (bun) plates, and rice dishes from pork chop to bo luc lac shaking beef. Among beverages, the familiar condensed-milk Vietnamese coffee is joined by modern innovations such as coffee with sea salt whipped cream, and a host of milk teas.

Greek-American favorites at George’s Place West

1050 NJ-47 South, Rio Grande, 609-435-5010, kararestaurantgroup.com/georges-west. Breakfast, lunch, dinner.

If you’ve eaten brunch in Cape May County, chances are you’ve eaten at George’s — a nearly 50-year-old tradition of Greek-American dining on the Shore, more recently expanded into an empire by brothers Yianni and Peter Karapanagiotis.

Just as new freeway lanes bring traffic seemingly from nowhere, each new George’s location brings new crowds to fill it. New brunch lines for tiramisu waffles and Greek omelets. New lunch lines for gyro and falafel. And plenty of dinner reservations for braised lamb shank or branzino.

A fifth location, George's West, just opened in Rio Grande, west of Wildwood. And if the past is any judge, this too will inspire lines for brunch. But maybe, just maybe, you can get there first.

Coming soon:

Steak and seafood next to a pool bar and nightclub: Fairview Social in the Seaport Suites

3601 Pacific Ave., Wildwood. bgcap.co. Openng projected by Memorial Day 2023.

Among the biggest projects to hit Wildwood this year, the 64-room Seaport Suites hotel will open as soon as Memorial Day at the former site of the once-legendary Fairview club and music venue.

On the bottom floor will be an eventual trio of ambitious projects from BG Capital, the developers behind nearby Seaport Pier: This will include a pool "day club" with two outdoor bars called Fourcast, an indoor bar and venue called Vice, and a 189-seat restaurant and bar called Fairview Social helmed by a former chef at multiple former Trump properties.

Head chef Stephen Johnson's menu is under development, but needless to say, there will be steak. And there will be seafood.

The restaurant will offer an "elevated" dining experience and decor, but with none of the stuffiness of fine dining, said operating manager Jason Weiss, a longtime DJ and event promoter. Think old-school high banquettes and high-top tables, he said, and a bar through the center of the space, TVs tuned to every sporting event that exists.

In part, the restaurant is meant to pay homage to the classic nightclub that gave Fairview Social its name, Weiss said.

"We're trying to really keep the decor and the vibe and the feelings of that old space intact here," he said. "We actually want people to feel like they're revisiting things from their childhood and from growing up."

Fresh moozadell and Brooklyn-style subs: Charlie’s Sandwich Shop

5400 Pacific Ave., Wildwood, charliessandwichshopsi.com. Planned by end of May.

Brooklyn-style Italian subs are coming to Wildwood.

For years, co-owners Calogero Bellomo and Charles Tornabene have made glistening braids of fresh mozzarella cheese and old-school Italian sandwiches in Brooklyn and Staten Island, whether a chicken-cutle "Malaka" or a salami and fresh-moozadell “Gonzo.”

For a lot longer, Tornabene has been coming down with his family to Wildwood. Finally, he figured, maybe he “oughta bring a little piece of Brooklyn in here.”

Tornabene promises fresh bread each day from New York. They’ll make the mozzarella. They’ll cook up their own roast beef on special. They’ll do everything they do in Brooklyn, Tornabene said: antipasto platters and caprese salads, a “Papa Sal” chicken parm with fried eggplant, a mortadella-and-pepper number called the “Humidor.”

Charlie's hopes to be open by Memorial Day.

“We grew up goin’ to Wildwood every summer as kids,” Tornabene said. “So why not just plant a seed there? You know what I mean?”

Thick-slab cheesesteaks from Philly: Steve’s Prince of Steaks

2701 New Jersey Ave., Wildwood. stevesprinceofsteaks.com. Planned for July.

Steve’s Prince of Steaks is coming to Wildwood.

Steve’s, if you don’t know, is a 40-year classic in the world of Philadelphia cheesesteaks: a Northeast Philly stalwart founded by namesake Steven Iliescu. The shop is well known for its slab-style thick-cut beef, with devout loyalty among those who want cheesesteak that looks like steak.

The shop already has two locations in Northeast Philly, and a third in the Northeast suburb of Langhorne, all run by the Iliescu family. The Wildwood location, opening as soon as July in the space formerly home to Classic Sandwiches, will be the first Steve’s franchise.

Bowling, food, drink, arcades and more: Cape Square Entertainment Center

3801 US-9, Rio Grande. squaretheatres.com. Projected for end of May.

Sleepy Rio Grande will get a little less sleepy and a lot more filled with bowling balls.

After years in gestation, a former Kmart shopping center and vacant movie theater is set to become a massive entertainment complex. Cape Square Entertainment Center has long been in the works from developer Town Square Entertainment, which has brought multiple movie theaters to life along the South Jersey shore.

Town Square and the operators at the site have been a bit mum about the details and didn’t respond to requests for comment. But plans floated over the years have included two restaurants — one upscale, one casual — nine movie theater screens, a virtual golf course, an arcade and a 12-lane bowling alley.

The restaurants, whose details have not been announced, will come from some of the same people behind Jersey Shore spots like Capt'n Jacks Island Grill, Harbor Burger Bar and the new Nucky's Speakeasy in Ventnor, according to people familiar with the project.

The center is set to be open as soon as Memorial Day, according to a March article by The Press of Atlantic City, citing Cape May County counsel Jeff Lindsay.

So whatever’s coming … it may be coming quite soon.

Matthew Korfhage is a Philadelphia-based writer for USA Today Network.

search_result.title: Table Talk: The food of 'Downton Abbey'
search_result.text:
DEBBIE SALOMON

With the curtain falling on “Downton Abbey,” the best soap opera ever to cross the pond, I must revisit the food element which — although less-pronounced than in “The Sopranos” — extrapolated a lifestyle. If you haven’t watched, for shame. Find someone who owns the entire series, or chip in with friends and order the DVDs from Amazon. I watch mine often enough to know the script by heart, yet every time I notice something new. Costumes are astounding, relationships complicated, societal strictures hilarious when not irritating. The plot line covers contemporary themes from an early 20th century perspective: single parenthood, breast cancer, rape, war, homosexuality, women’s rights, premarital sex, abortion, anti-Semitism, class distinction … and food.

Nearly half the action takes place in the kitchen/servants’ quarters. Shakespeare couldn’t have written Mrs. Patmore, the rotund, wispy-haired cook, any better. Ditto Daisy, the kitchen maid and, especially, Mr. Moseley — the eternal loser.

Much interaction among members of the titled Crawley family happens around the dining room table. Notice these:

•The family dresses formally for dinner, every night, guests or not. Meals are multi-course, including soup, meat and fish entrees, a “savory” (appetizer), fresh vegetables and a dessert called “pudding,” no matter how fancy. Remember the Charlotte Russe Ethel made for lunch (called “luncheon”) after Sybil’s death in childbirth? Yet all the women stay skinny as worms.

•Tea in the library includes several cakes; servants’ tea is always bread and butter. But the bread is homemade, looks delicious, better than the cakes. Similarly, servants eat mostly “stew and semolina” for their late supper – probably 10 p.m. – although wine is sometimes present. Breakfast? Forever porridge.

•Few specific dishes are mentioned except when Isabel’s new cook burns a kidney soufflé. Yuck. She redeems herself with salmon mousse. And every proper lady’s maid is expected to make a “restorative broth,” no doubt a precursor to “Chicken Soup for the Soul.” Mrs. Patmore’s training is never specified, yet she produces a wedding brunch for Edith which includes calvados-glazed duckling, lobster rissoles, asparagus salad with saffron vinaigrette. These elaborations, all adapted from a menu served on the Titanic, end up on the servants’ table after Edith is jilted at the altar. Footman Alfred calls them “pickty bits” and asks for cheese.

Yet new kitchen helper Ivy’s first solo dish is a feuillete — asparagus wrapped in puff pastry.

Eventually, Alfred leaves to apprentice in the Ritz kitchen – a most unlikely occupation for a country lad.

•Married women have breakfast in bed; American-born Lady Grantham (Cora) notices fresh-squeezed OJ on her tray, the result of research on American customs done by a fawning new maid. Mrs. Patmore is pleasantly surprised when Cora’s Yankee mom, played dead-pan by Shirley MacLaine, doesn’t balk at offal – the organ meats (liver, kidney, tripe, sweetbreads) popular in England.

•Newfangled appliances arrive with negative fanfare; housekeeper Mrs. Hughes “treats herself” to an electric toaster which smokes up the downstairs. Mrs. Patmore breaks the bowl of an electric stand mixer (on purpose?) and rants against a refrigerator. So how did they manage ice cream, which Lady Mary remembers eating as a child, in the 1890s?

•Food becomes a weapon of revenge when then-chauffeur Tom Branson stirs up a potage of soap, vinegar and cow dung with which he plans to douse a high-ranking military official dining at the abbey. Who can forget Daisy using salt instead of sugar in a “pudding” for guests, so the Crawleys would not prefer the cooking of a substitute while Mrs. Patmore was indisposed?

Then, it is Mrs. P’s cooking that attracts a suitor more interested in her pate than her personality. Luckily, she sees through him before he chains her to yet another stove.

•In Season Four, Cora’s monkey-business brother, played by Paul Giametti, comes to visit, bemoaning British food. Yet he is impressed by Daisy’s kedgeree. Never heard of it, so I googled the mishmash composed of hard boiled eggs, rice, smoked fish and Indian seasonings, served at weekend brunch.

•Edibles provided a few laughs, as when the barn cat tries to run away with a whole roast chicken and Lord Grantham’s dog Isis catches a crepe Mrs. Patmore tossed into the air; also when footman Alfred accidentally dumps a platter of shellfish on the Dowager Countess’s (Maggie Smith) lap.

•There are tender moments: Carson, the butler, patiently teaches Alfred uses for seven different spoons, including bouillon. Upstairs and downstairs women unite to mount a soup kitchen for destitute World War I veterans. Star-crossed lovers Anna and Bates take a picnic into the Scottish Highlands. Lady Mary, after auditioning Tony Gillingham as a lover, orders room service in their hotel hideaway. The flaming Christmas pudding, the cake culinary neophyte Lady Sybil bakes to surprise her mother, the “egg for Miss Sibbie’s tea” ordered by a wicked nanny …those, and much more.

Did I whet your appetite? “Downton Abbey” will satisfy … in so many ways.

Contact Debbie Salomon at debsalomon@nc.rr.com

search_result.title: Bazaar's tasty traditions root Jewish community
search_result.text:
Sherry Lucas

The Clarion-Ledger

Now in its 49th year, the Beth Israel Sisterhood Bazaar's annual spread of hearty ethnic foods and sweet treats can hardly still qualify as exotic. At least not to the nearly 1,000 people who annual drop by for take-out or pull up a chair inside.

Chicken soup with matzo balls, noodle kugel, carrot tzimmes, brisket, potato knishes histories that stretch back centuries and echo from an ocean away.

The bazaar, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. March 30, includes traditional Jewish food, deli sandwiches, casseroles, gourmet desserts, a silent auction, white elephant sale and a raffle. Work starts each January with group cooks to supply the freeze-well dishes that'll supply the hot plate line and frozen casserole stash. The Sisterhood's largest fundraiser of the year, it supports service programs and groups such as Stewpot, Henry S. Jacobs camp, Meals on Wheels, Salvation Army and more. And it's a temple-wide effort; the Men's Club rallies to the occasion, frying up the popular blintzes on bazaar day.

Lunch time typically sees the biggest rush, with eat-in and carry-out orders snapping up many Jewish cultural staples.

Different families have different traditions as far as the meals go, said Cheryl Katz, co-president with Mindy Humphrey of the Beth Israel Sisterhood. "Everybody's stuffed cabbage is different." And so, recipes for the bazaar foods that feed the masses may change a bit, too, as committee chairmanships pass from one person to the next. 'Sometimes they tweak it to what their family is eating."

Holiday deals: Shop this season’s top products and sales curated by our editors.

The menu touches on foods from traditions ranging from Eastern Europe to Israel (hummus, baba ghanoush, tabbouli, chopped liver) to New York delis (reuben, corned beef), to satisfy a wide range of preferences.

But the taster plate on the hot food line may be a greatest hits collection. Here's the back story on its cultural staples:

Kugel, rooted in Eastern Europe's Ashkenazi Jews, may have a history stretching back more than eight centuries and can be a dessert or savory side depending on the style. Early on, before sugar sweetened the landscape and for the vast majority of regular folk, kugel was a baked pudding. Noodles, eggs, cheese and/or milk joined the dish via German Jews, rendering a creamy casserole. Potatoes or matzo flour might form the base rather than noodles, with vegetables and onions added for extra flavor. But no meat (mixing meat with milk wasn't kosher).

Sugar sweetened it up it up in the 1600s, and fruit such as raisins became common in sweet kugel, which has outdistanced its savory older cousin in popularity. The sweet noodle kugel — rich with dairy, sweetened with raisins, its crunchy top a pleasant contrast to the yielding custardy pasta — is a specialty at the bazaar.

Stuffed cabbage — cooked cabbage leaves wrapped around fillings, usually beef and rice — stretch back about 2,000 years in Jewish cooking, with recipes and preferences among European Jews varying by region.

Potato knishes trace roots, too, back to Eastern European Jewish heritage, immigrants in the early 20th century popularized this staple/snack food in New York City. Simple, fast and filling, the pastry-covered knishes could be spicy or sweet. At a deli, the pastry-covered knish can be about the size of a bagel; at the bazaar, petite-sized potato knishes fit on the taster plate or qualify as appetizers.

Tzimmes, a traditional sweet stew of simmered carrots and dried fruits such as raisins and/or prunes (and often with other root vegetables), hails from Ashkenazi Jewish tradition, with honey or sugar, orange juice and occasionally cinnamon or other spices adding even more flavor. Because of all the prep work hat goes into slicing and stirring, the name may claim parentage in Yiddish tzim (for) and esn (eating); the expression "make a big tzimmes over something," means making a big fuss, according to unitedwithisrael.org.

Brisket, the flavorful cut of beef from the cow's chest, is best braised to bypass its tough and stringy tendencies. The ease, time involved and better-the-next-day qualities made it a reliable and traditional staple for big meals, from Rosh Hashana to Passover.

Chicken soup with matzo balls — sometimes referred to as "Jewish penicillin" for its curative powers — includes a dumpling made of matzo meal with eggs, water and oil or chicken fat (schmaltz).

Blintzes hark back to Hungarian origin, and the creamy cheese filling of the crepes is sometimes augmented with jam or sour cream for an even sweeter, richer treat.

The Beth Isreal Bazaar "is probably one of the oldest, in relative terms, and beloved Jewish food festivals in the South," said Marcie Cohen Ferris, author of "Matzoh Ball Gumbo: Culinary Tales of the Jewish South." "Beth Israel has really made a name for themselves, particularly because it's in Mississippi." Ask American Jews to name the most surprising place Jews live, "it's Alaska and Mississippi," she said.

"To have a really vibrant, well-established Jewish food festival/bazaar that's meant so much for so long ... is really significant. It has really strong meaning particularly in Jackson because it was a way for that Jewish community to say we are here. We are committed to this state. We are Mississippians, but we have these cherished religious and ethnic food traditions. And it's important to us, like other church folks, to share this with you.

"That's what people do in the South and at churches and synagogues," with bazaars, festivals and cake sales.

"It's exotic, but it's familiar because people know those Jewish community members."

Katz said, "It's a Jackson tradition now."

search_result.title: No beef: Park City saloon specializes in bison burgers
search_result.text:
Larry Olmsted

Special for USA TODAY

The scene: When the snow starts flying this winter, Park City, Utah, will be catapulted into the global spotlight as the new home of the largest ski resort in the United States. Opening in December, the new Park City ski area is a merger of what were formerly the Park City Mountain Resort and Canyons, interconnected with new lifts and trails. The behemoth will feature 38 lifts and 300-plus runs, including a chair and trail right down to the town’s historic Main Street — just a few blocks from the No Name Saloon.

The former silver mining town has long been a ski travel hot spot, but the seismic change will make already popular Main Street eateries like the No Name Saloon even harder to get into. But you need not wait until winter, as Park City has increasingly become a year-round destination, with plenty of great hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, and other mountain town activities. A brand-new 18-hole public golf course just opened at the Canyons base area a month ago. Plus, it’s a lot easier to go out to eat, and when you do, you can eat outside.

Park City is an upscale town, home to many luxury hotels, boutiques, art galleries and the Sundance Film Festival. It does not really have any dive bars, but the No Name Saloon is about as close as it gets. Entering it feels a bit like stepping back in time to the Old West, with a Victorian-style saloon featuring worn wooden floors, an ornate bar with multi-level shelves and mirrors, and old-school ceiling fans all driven by a single linked belt. Imagine a cowboy bar, with stools at the bar and a jumble of high-top tables jammed in as close together as possible for dining. Now imagine taking anything and everything the owners could find and hanging it on walls and from the ceiling — including Christmas lights, a tricycle, toy cars, a moose head, sports trophies and a full-size old motorcycle and a very old snowmobile. Bathrooms are marked with pictures of Popeye and Betty Boop. A flat-screen TV is jammed in among the miscellany, silently playing sports while loud music cranks — every second or third song is Led Zeppelin.

That’s the front bar cum dining room. The place is a bit of a maze that continues backwards past the narrow kitchen with more tables hidden in back, even more upstairs, and in summer, more outside. Everywhere you turn is interesting stuff, from well-used bar shuffleboard to old license plates to an antique high wheel bicycle. Just as there is little order to the layout and design, there is no order to the seating, and when busy it’s every guest for themselves, with hovering/stalking rewarded while less aggressive diners may never get seated. In peak ski season, it is easiest to come for lunch or après, while for dinner, expect a (potentially fruitless) wait.

Reason to visit: Buffalo burgers.

The food: The No Name Saloon is a bar, and it is all about bar food, served fast and on red-and-white checked paper in red plastic baskets. But it is very good bar food with several unique twists. Still, it would be somewhat unremarkable save for a confluence of highlights: its great location in arguably the nation’s hottest ski town, its century-plus of history and undeniably colorful atmosphere, and its focus on bison.

Buffalo is increasingly common and for good reason: It tastes great, it’s likely better for you than beef and it is definitely more natural. While the vast majority of beef cattle in this country are raised on a steady diet of antibiotics, hormones and food they don’t consume naturally, bison receive no drugs and eat grass. It also happens to make a great-tasting burger, and I often use it at home. It shows up more and more on menus, but has been the signature here forever — so much so that the No Name Saloon offers no “regular” burgers. There are turkey and veggie alternatives, along with bar food staples like tacos, hot wings, quesadillas and fish and chips.

The burgers are served in several distinct styles, always with “buffalo chips and salsa,” which are actually very good house-made kettle-style potato chips, an unusual pairing. The potato chips and salsa are also offered as a starter and as a side can be upgraded to fries or onion rings, both of which are well above average. The fries are fresh and crunchy and really taste like potato, while the rings are the widely varied size that comes from cutting up actual onions rather than using a frozen bag, tasty and crispy.

The burger patties are an extremely generous 1/2-pound of bison, and since it has less fat to begin with, it shrinks less than a beef burger, making it seem even bigger. While they have the basic burger offerings, the house signature No Name Burger is unusual, topped with a mound of cream cheese studded with sliced jalapenos, plus lettuce, tomato and mayo spread underneath. I was hesitant to eat it, as I wouldn’t usually put cream cheese on a burger in lieu of say cheddar, but I tried it and it was excellent. The buffalo patty itself is really good, while the aioli, cream cheese and jalapeño worked well together. I also got to taste test a range of styles with the clever buffalo slider trio, and the barbecue bacon cheeseburger was my favorite.

There is something both homey and cheesy about the place. Service is frenetic but friendly, and given all that is going on and how dense the crowds they push through, I have to commend the wait staff on their non-stop smiles and attitude. It can be a bit of a chore to eat at No Name, especially for dinner on a busy night, but the food makes it worthwhile, better than it looks and better than you might expect. All this, plus lots of local craft beers on tap and a good happy hour make it what it wants to be: a great ski town bar.

Pilgrimage-worthy?: No, but if you are in Park City and want a great burger — or have never tried buffalo.

Rating: Mmmm (Scale: Blah, OK, Mmmm, Yum!, OMG!)

Price: $$ ($ cheap, $$ moderate, $$$ expensive)

Details: 447 Main Street, Park City, Utah; 435-649-6667; nonamesaloon.net

Larry Olmsted has been writing about food and travel for more than 15 years. An avid eater and cook, he has attended cooking classes in Italy, judged a barbecue contest and once dined with Julia Child. search_result.title: What is a Maid-Rite? How many loose-meat sandwich restaurants ...
search_result.text:
Just curious: This occasional feature in the Des Moines Register aims to answer your questions about Iowa. Is there some place, event, lore, history or cultural quirk you're just curious about? Email your question to the Des Moines Register's Bill Steiden at wsteiden@registermedia.com.

Have you ever had a Maid-Rite?

Iowa's loose-meat sandwich — perhaps second only to the pork tenderloin as the state's most famous culinary concoction between two buns — is known as a Maid-Rite after the brand of franchise restaurants that sell the sandwich.

One of the oldest fast-food restaurants in the United States, the Maid-Rite has nearly a century of history, and hungry Iowans are still filling up on the sandwiches alongside fries and a shake.

What is a Maid-Rite loose-meat sandwich?

If you've ever seen the classic sitcom "Roseanne," you might remember references to the loose-meat sandwich.

The classic sandwich has crumbly, finely-ground and seasoned beef on a bun. Diners can add condiments like ketchup, mustard, onions or pickles. Cheese is an option for a Cheese-Rite or bacon for a bacon Cheese-Rite.

Imagine a burger just with crumbled beef instead of a pressed patty. A Maid-Rite is distinct, in that sense, from a sloppy Joe, which is doused in a tomato sauce.

Other possible varieties includes a Maid-Rite with chili; a Maid-Rite bowl; a Jalapeño-Rite; a mega version with a larger pile of meat; a Maid-Rite with barbecue sauce; or rarebit version, served open-faced with melted cheese.

Maid-Rite restaurants might serve fries, shakes, tenderloins and other diner-style food for a full meal. Local Maid-Rite franchises might also offer breakfast, homemade pies or unique ice cream flavors.

Where did the Maid-Rite come from?

As the Des Moines Register has previously reported, Fred Angell was running a butcher shop in Muscatine in 1926 and was experimenting with a new way to cook hamburger.

A salesman who later came by and took a sample then exclaimed, as the story goes, "this sandwich is made right."

Angell opened up a restaurant in Muscatine to sell his invention, and the brand grew to an early example of a fast-food franchise with drive-in service.

An early franchise was Taylor's Maid-Rite in Marshalltown, which opened in 1928 under Cliff Taylor and remains open and family-owned to this day.

Where can I get a Maid-Rite?

The Maid-Rite website lists about 25 Maid-Rite franchises in the Midwest, though a few on the list appear to now be closed.

In Iowa, there are 15 franchise locations, according to Google business listings. They're anywhere from a suburban strip mall, a small town downtown or even a highway welcome center with an Amish country store.

There's just one in Des Moines proper: at the food court in Merle Hay Mall, 3800 Merle Hay Road. Other locations in the Des Moines metro include Ankeny, 802 S.E. Oralabor Road, and Norwalk, 1031 Sunset Drive.

The historic Taylor's Maid-Rite in downtown Marshalltown is at 106 S. Third Ave. and Oskaloosa's Maid-Rite at 902 A Ave. W.

Other Iowa Maid-Rite locations include Davenport, Cedar Falls, Cedar Rapids, Dubuque, Durant, Lamoni, Muscatine, Waterloo, and West Burlington.

The Newton Maid-Rite, with almost 100 years of history in town, recently added donuts back to the menu after a three-year hiatus, the Newton Daily News reported. Dan Holtkamp previously owned the restaurant for 51 years through 2021, according to the Daily News.

There are also restaurants in Iowa that serve their own spin on a loose-meat sandwich under a different name, such as Paula's Cafe in West Des Moines, Ottumwa's institution Canteen Lunch in the Alley or Awe'z Sandwich Shop in Mason City.

Maid-Rite locations also remain open in Illinois, Minnesota and Missouri.

Chris Higgins covers the northern and eastern suburbs for the Register. Reach him at chiggins@registermedia.com or 515-423-5146 and follow him on Twitter @chris_higgins_.

search_result.title: Phish inspired Firefly Music Festival, what to know about Mondegreen
search_result.text:
Once upon a time, long before the birth of Phish's Mondegreen festival in Delaware, the Vermont jam band that sings about lizard people decided to do something pretty whimsical.

Phish launched its first self-created festival in the '90s, which helped to pave the way for Firefly Music Festival in The Woodlands of Dover.

That's right. Not only is Phish bringing their new Mondegreen festival to The Woodlands on Thursday, Aug. 15, to Sunday, Aug. 18 — the band also has had a major influence on Firefly, which is slated to return this year.

Here's the lowdown on how Phish inspired Firefly, and what Phish fans need to know before coming to The Woodlands for Mondegreen.

Phish blazed trail for Firefly Music Festival

The first Phish festival was the three-day Clifford Ball in Plattsburgh, New York, in 1996. That event helped to set the template for the band's future festivals.

Mondegreen continues the band's tradition and is slated to be Phish's 11th self-produced festival.

Clifford Ball revolutionized the festival scene and is responsible for inspiring other major events like Bonnaroo, which launched in 2002 in Tennessee. The band played the festival in 2009, 2012 and 2019.

“There's no underplaying the significance that Phish had, as a band and as an organization, in the direct development of Bonnaroo,” said Bonnaroo festival co-founder Rick Farman in a 2019 report by The Tennessean, a sister publication to Delaware Online/The News Journal.

Trey Anastasio of Phish on when 'There were no festivals'

Phish also helped to influence Firefly, a festival born in 2012 in The Woodlands that shares a similar DNA as Bonnaroo. Both festivals are four days and each features about 100 acts, some of which have headlined both events.

(Firefly promised to return in 2024 after taking the year off to recalibrate in 2023. But festival organizers haven’t announced a lineup or dates for this year's event.)

Believe it or not, there was once a time when music festivals were few in the United States. Major concert promoters chose to build amphitheaters instead.

But in the ‘90s, Phish broke the mold by holding epic, ambitious and fiercely independent gatherings in remote corners of the country, and brought up to 85,000 fans along with them.

Phish also was the only act on their festival lineup, a theme they'll continue at Mondegreen.

“There were no festivals,” recalled Phish frontman Trey Anastasio in the 2019 report by The Tennessean. “And I mean none. It was not something that had a blueprint. The only festival that we could have conjured up in America would be Woodstock — the real one — which was logistically, an unmitigated disaster. So when we started planning our first festival, the first thing on our minds was to make it really comfortable for our friends, which were our fans.”

Where are The Woodlands Dover?

The Woodlands in Dover, Delaware, home to the festival, is a rural area off the main Route 1 highway. Civilization is only about a 15-minute drive. Within that driving radius festivalgoers will find lots of businesses like Walmart, Target, gas stations (Wawa), grocery stores (Safeway, Redner's), restaurants (Chipotle, Grotto Pizza, McDonald's, etc.) and the Dover Mall.

Where is the closest airport or train to The Woodlands Dover?

The closest train station is upstate in Wilmington (roughly 51 minutes). Amtrak's Acela offers routes between Wilmington; Philadelphia; New York; Boston; New Haven, Connecticut; and Washington, D.C.

Festivalgoers will find the nearest airport is Wilmington Airport (38 minutes). This Wilmington location offers budget prices, but the only caveat is they serve only select cities. For a complete listing, visit flyilg.com.

Other nearby airports are Philadelphia International Airport (1 hour and 15 minutes) and Baltimore's BWI Airport (1 hour and 45 minutes).

What's it like in The Woodlands?

The festival grounds are massive, which means you might want to wear some comfy shoes. The Woodlands also includes areas where folks can set up hammocks.

One of the downsides to The Woodlands is it doesn't offer a lot of shade from the sun. It's likely The Woodlands will shrink significantly for the Phish festival, which would help revelers cut down on walking.

Dover Motor Speedway is near The Woodlands

Each year NASCAR fans camp out in The Woodlands to see their favorite drivers race at the nearby Dover Motor Speedway, formerly Dover International Speedway, and nicknamed the Monster Mile. The Woodlands are on the outskirts of the iconic racetrack.

How is Wi-Fi in The Woodlands?

Internet access was hit-or-miss at Firefly. Some people used their phone as a hotspot to access the Web.

What does Mondegreen mean?

Mondegreen is defined as "a word or phrase that results from a mishearing, especially of something recited or sung," according to Merriam-Webster.

When are Mondegreen tickets on sale?

Travel packages went on sale Thursday, Jan. 18, at 11 a.m. EST. Weekend and camping passes go on sale Friday, Jan. 19. at 11 a.m. EST.

General admission starts at $450 and covers access for all four days. If you're bringing a vehicle, you must also buy a camping or parking vehicle pass (1 per car or RV). Parking passes (day or overnight) start at $40.

Mondegreen is in The Woodlands near Dover Motor Speedway (1131 N. Dupont Highway, Dover) from Thursday, Aug. 15, to Sunday, Aug. 18. For more info, visit mondegreen.phish.com.

The Tennessean reporter Dave Paulson contributed to this article.

search_result.title: 10 Phish facts before they play Delaware festival in Woodlands Dover
search_result.text:
The legendary jam band Phish is as polarizing as fanny packs, comedian Amy Schumer, and pineapple pizza.

This popular crew from Vermont has been grooving listeners since the 1980s.

They're on pace to reel in a big school of Phish fans for their new four-day festival, called Mondegreen, in The Woodlands of Dover from Thursday, Aug. 15, to Sunday, Aug. 18.

Meanwhile, here are some interesting Phish facts for folks to dive into about the band.

Fans receive macaroni from Phish

There are lots of unique ways to make DIY music shakers. Phish fans discovered this when the band handed them boxes of macaroni to be used for percussion tools when they played Slade Hall at the University of Vermont on Sept. 27, 1985, according to Phish.net, the popular Phish forum where fans leaked the band's Woodlands festival a month before Phish officially went public.

Phish plays vacuum cleaner in concert

Drummer Jon Fishman is skilled at playing melodies on a vacuum cleaner. There are multiple videos of him on YouTube holding a vacuum hose to his mouth and creating quirky sounds with it during his vacuum solo. One YouTube video is titled “Phish 11-30-19 Vacuum Solo.”

Lead singer Trey Anastasio can play drums

When Fishman is doing his vacuum solo, who's on the drums? Lead singer Trey Anastasio has filled in for his bandmate behind a drum set. Anastasio joins a unique list of singers who also play drums like Dave Grohl (who has vacationed in Rehoboth Beach), Ringo Starr, Teddy Pendergrass and Phil Collins. You can watch Anastasio in action in the above vacuum solo video.

Phish's hot dog is in Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, not the band

For years there's been a debate whether Phish will ever be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame. There honestly isn't a clear answer. The irony is the band has a famous hot-dog prop that's featured at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in Ohio. The band first rode the iconic hot dog at their Boston Garden concert on Dec 31, 1994.

Page McConnell's dad developed Tylenol

Born in nearby Philadelphia and raised in New Jersey, keyboardist Page McConnell was destined to make musical medicine that would heal the masses. His dad, Jack, worked for the McNeil Pharmaceutical Co. (later Johnson & Johnson) and helped develop Tylenol, according to a 2007 report by ABC.

Phish co-founder becomes a politician

Not all Phish members can be branded as one-dimensional musicians, especially percussionist Jon Fishman (who inspired the band's name, according to encyclopedia.com). Fishman's résumé also includes becoming a politician as he drummed up excitement in his hometown of Lincolnville, Maine, after becoming the newest selectman to win an election to the five-member select board in 2017.

Dress-wearing Phish member does movie with Bernie Sanders

Fishman has had a knack for wearing doughnut dresses in concert over the years. That might explain why he's credited as playing Ginger the "transvestite" drummer" in the 1999 film "My X-Girlfriend's Wedding Reception," per IMDB. Another Vermont legend in the film is Fishman's friend Sen. Bernie Sanders, who plays a rabbi in the flick. Fishman is a longtime supporter of Sanders and endorsed him when he was on the campaign trail in 2016.

Who is the fifth member of Phish?

It's common for bands to embrace members who aren't one of the group's founding musicians. But it's unusual when that adopted member is the lighting guy. Chris Kuroda, the band's lighting director, is the fifth official star Phish in the group. (It even says so on the band's website.)

Phish college thesis is on improvisation

The ability to ad-lib in concert is a cornerstone for Phish. McConnell takes it seriously, so much so that he based his senior thesis around it when he attended Goddard College in Vermont. His thesis, which was published in 1987, was titled "The Art of Improvisation," per McConnell's bio.

Phish has a 'Triple Nipple'

The jam band references nipples getting sliced in three songs, a theme nicknamed the "Triple Nipple." In the song "Fee," the band sings: "Floyd is dead; he's nothing but a ripple/Cause Milly took that paper/And sliced him on the nipple."

There's also the tune "Sloth":

“I'm So bad. He's so nasty Ain't got no friends. Real out-casty Stay out of my way. End up a cripple I'll take this piece of paper. [Cross?] your nipple.”

The third song about nipples is "Punch You in The Eye":

"Well it seems you didn't like my face I quickly learned that Prussia was an evil place They tied me to a chair with a giant clip And held a piece of paper to my tender nip."

search_result.title: Firefly Music Festival cancels 2024 event in The Woodlands of Dover
search_result.text:
The organizers of Firefly Music Festival finally addressed the elephant in the room and announced Thursday that the festival won't return this year, for the second straight year.

"Firefly Music Festival will not return in 2024," the festival organizers posted on their Facebook page at noon. "We look forward to powering Firefly's lights back on someday when the timing is right, but until then, The Woodlands will continue to host new music events for years to come. Keep on dancing, fam."

Firefly fans: 'They are trying to break up with us'

In late 2022, after its 10th Firefly event, festival producers AEG Presents promised Firefly would come back to The Woodlands of Dover in 2024, before the festival went on hiatus last summer to "recharge our lights."

Until this Thursday afternoon, the organizers hadn't made any announcements on its Facebook or Instagram page, which led fans to assume the festival wasn't coming back in 2024, or possibly ever again.

Firefly fans expressed a mix of heartbreak and fond memories under the festival's Facebook page following the post.

"Please please please I cannot beg any more, please just figure stuff out and make damn sure to be back again sometime soon then!!!" a passionate fan demanded.

"Thank you for the memories, and the closure," another person said.

"I feel like they are trying to break up with us but still leaving a shred of hope. Not cool lol," one fan claimed.

Why was Firefly canceled in 2023 & 2024?

Firefly organizers never elaborated on why the festival went dark this year or in 2023. But last week we reported that it was reasonable to assume the festival's struggling attendance played a key role in that.

Organizers likely needed time to figure out a good strategy to rejuvenate interest in their event, a theory that appears to be validated by their latest Facebook post.

Attendance at Firefly has dipped

At its height in 2015, Firefly attracted 90,000 fans. That was the same year Paul McCartney headlined. But since then, the festival has shrunk.

In 2019, Firefly reduced from four to three days (Friday through Sunday), which trimmed the crowd down to maybe about 60,000 fans. Firefly organizers have been shy about releasing attendance stats for their festival since their 2015 event.

Firefly would return back to four days for its 2021 and 2022 events. Organizers announced they were capping the 2021 festival at about 50,000 people, which helped them meet the state's COVID-19 restrictions.

Despite the capped attendance, the fan excitement at the 2021 event was still strong, with plenty of first-timers.

But hosting the festival in late September of 2021 and 2022 made it more difficult for its high school and college-age crowd to attend.

Firefly competes against more festivals like Oceans Calling

There are multiple reasons why Firefly has dimmed over the years. One reason is the festival landscape is more competitive now than when Firefly launched in 2012.

New festivals have popped up like Oceans Calling in Ocean City, Maryland, which debuted last year. That event catered to old-school Firefly fans who wanted to see more rock bands and '90s/2000s acts, and it featured Firefly alum.

This week Oceans Calling dropped its lineup for their fall event, which has doubled down on those types of acts and features headliners The Dave Matthews Band, Blink-182 and The Killers, the former of which both played Firefly.

The festival's lineup has received rave reviews from concert lovers. Some commenters even mentioned Oceans Calling under Firefly's latest Facebook post.

"Yeah that Oceans Calling Festival is taking you alls mojo," one person said.

Firefly got younger; older fans left

Another reason some Firefly fans abandoned the festival is because it began to attract a high school crowd. Firefly started out as an indie/alternative rock festival.

In 2022, News Journal reporter Ryan Cormier pointed out: "Over the years, pop, hip-hop and electronic music overtook rock as the dominant sound of the festival, which eventually lost much of its older fan base and saw more teenage and college-aged music fans coming to the 300-acre site."

Is Firefly dead?Fans share some of their issues with the festival

Phish festival Mondegreen comes to The Woodlands Dover

It's no secret AEG has a working history with Phish and has partnered with the jam band to help them with their Mondegreen festival, coming to The Woodlands this summer from Aug. 15 to 18.

AEG's efforts are more focused on making that a success, an event that's buzzing, than shifting its attention to Firefly this year. That festival is a surefire way to bring in lots of attendance because the Phish community is very loyal and has a reputation for traveling the country to see the band.

What's next for Firefly Music Festival?

As the Firefly promoters mentioned in their update on Thursday, fans shouldn't be surprised to see them hosting more festivals in The Woodlands.

The reality is there's not that much pressure for a new Firefly to bounce back tomorrow because AEG's lease for exclusive festival rights to the Firefly site for music festivals extends to 2032.

So it sounds like the promoters plan to bring big events to Delaware for years to come.

Delaware Online reporter Ryan Cormier contributed to this report.
